title: Photo Deconstruction: Complementary Gels & 4-Light Setup
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler deconstructs a high-contrast studio portrait, demonstrating how to use color theory with complementary blue and orange gels across a four-light setup to create a graphic, popping image.

steps.action: Set up the main light on the left to hit the set and subject front.
Add a rim light on the right side using a strip softbox to match the blue tone from the opposite direction.
steps.tool: Profoto D2 + 1x4ft Strip Softbox + Blue Gel

steps.action: Place a light on a floor stand behind the subject, pointed at the white background to create a warm sunset gradient.
Add a fourth light with a tight grid to hit the subject's face with warm light, unifying her with the background.
Configure camera settings for the shot.
Apply post-processing: lift shadows to recover detail in blue areas, increase exposure slightly, add clarity for sparkle, and crop to square.

key_takeaways: Use complementary colors (like blue and orange) to create visual contrast and impact.
Cool colors tend to recede while warm colors pop, adding depth to the image.
When using colored gels on white walls, high intensity can shift colors (e.g., orange appearing yellow).
Post-processing is often needed to balance exposure between bright gelled backgrounds and darker gelled subjects.
